title: Communication, Language, and Early Literacy Development: 3-5 Years
subject: Early Childhood Standards of Quality (2022-)

document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

82EC5C5C27FC43EBB816E995A300BF3D.description: Begin to look over and modify their own writings and drawings.

7AE843814BF54AA392694656A94814AD.description: Begin to write words/letters representing words with spaces in between.

5D16BE76CF1C4689AC50692B4C88D85A.description: Write their name on drawings, dictation, and other works.

15AAF79135604223874919E1E7DFE536.description: Ask a familiar adult how to spell a word.

B7EE7A3BD1F04D77BECEC468725C63A7.description: Write words and stories using known words and invented spelling.

4372ED1FBB44413A91366C831003559A.description:
Begin to modify and add detail to their writing and drawings with prompting
and support.

62D6E30E9AFF40C4B201C724F5B872E2.description: Express their thoughts and feelings in text, writing letters and letter approximations as well as known words and invented spellings.

019111B121C94C6EA5F734088B380B5D.description: Use known letters and letter approximations to represent written words.

2BDB5FE75C9A4E3AB22F711AFC6B3566.description: Write some letters of the alphabet.

1F99CD4E7A93463BB122A3AC0FBA2FD4.description:
Print the letters in their own name in the correct order, most of the time, such
as when “signing in” to the learning environment.

FDC484D34E2C433B9E0590D2FB176327.description: Make marks on paper that are meant to represent letters.

951B6D9982A44917A5048122030A0DCA.description:
Make repeated marks on paper to represent lines and circles, with these
shapes growing clearer with experience over time.

18B6AC5A230C4D3BBA0ABB6319E9C2E4.description:
Show interest in using a variety of forms of early writing to convey meaning and represent sounds
and words.

D372D769B4884A619F199D2B91D1DCA6.description:
Use real and invented spelling to write notes and letters to familiar adults,
other children, and family members.

75BFBEDCFD524AEB9C0F742E6FCE03D4.description: Write text under a picture to describe the picture or tell a story.

05250E3240C44814924DBBB1822DCA0A.description: Draw pictures and write words to express their thoughts and ideas.

C4D41509FB20484FAF8A5F9CD0EE3C56.description: Use a tablet or computer to make words or write “stories.”

7431882BE05D46EA9055C577484D97A8.description:
Record their thoughts and ideas in a journal, including drawings, scribbles,
and invented spelling (or some combination of those).

B624B2D3B2CA4251BA5D7F60924280F4.description:
Write a note or story with drawings, letter approximations, and invented
spelling, and then ask a familiar adult to read it.

B21D40510D374EB195C42A46E27ED219.description: Explain the intended meaning of their writing and drawings.

E3E77E3CD1AD4F629357ED475D97E822.description:
Use invented spelling, drawings, and letter approximations to write a letter to
a friend or family member, sometimes.

0830AE5652CE4CF49E6E960D6AE1864E.description: Write a shopping list, menu, or party invitation during imaginative play.

0E3F1A8B27F140D08DDD28E441B4EDB4.description:
Print the letters in their own name from left to right, such as to “sign in” to the
learning environment.

6FDA1FB978FD43869A4955B9771CEB6A.description: Mimic the writing actions of familiar adults.

000D633A0F4E4C6284C68D7B4ECD51D7.description: Draw and scribble to represent a thought or something they’ve seen.

06AC3458FD334FBD8F24715A6578B716.description: Explain what their drawings or paintings represent.

9011655CAF3B48C7A3DE37DE3CD5E0C2.description: Ask a familiar adult what they are writing.

9997AF584D3444F798B3688B7D4D38B6.description: Develop an understanding that writing is a way of communicating for a variety of purposes.

03F208C70E464F4D8B462133F039E217.description: Use a tablet or computer to make words or write “stories.”

637D073B1A7A40F2894973313E947F5B.description:
Record their thoughts and ideas in a journal, including drawings, scribbles,
and invented spelling (or some combination of those).

ED605C0920EA428F8E5D176F75BA02D7.description: Practice making letters or words with a tablet or computer.

DDAA2419A91C4F8EA1CFCB7D5F9004D6.description: Use a variety of writing tools, such as pens, pencils, markers, colored pencils, etc.

9CCF58482E13489BA23798BF59F7DED5.description: Practice writing letter shapes in sand.

972D792361DF411A9098688353FD8F9E.description: Draw shapes, lines, and letters with their fingers in fingerpaint.

A1E8BD96899C40BBB2A5DC0DD4D25407.description: Attempt to draw letter shapes on paper with crayons or pencils.

DB3E7C7AE5354EBD8BE37FB3C3A31DE7.description: With guidance and support, explore a variety of writing tools and materials.

3B7E2E24A6584F599EDC6257FDCA0FD0.description:
Coordinate their movements with greater ease for complex tasks, such as
buttoning or cutting along a line.

DAC07B6799BF461FB54F3602E252C824.description:
Use a three-finger grasp (tripod grasp) with increasing confidence and ease
when holding drawing/writing tools.

7EF3E49C4D3B493392C79FAC8DD34F61.description:
Use a dominant hand for using paintbrushes, scissors, crayons, and other
tools.

6B6A058EEBF74F268C89D022DC3E75EE.description:
Begin to use a three-finger grasp (tripod grasp) when holding a pencil,
crayon, or other drawing/writing tools.

3FF1A326FE3047198B49AD0079616BAD.description: Draw letter-like forms with increasing accuracy and control.

A0D9DF58DE8244E9ACADC6351696CC2D.description:
Use scissors to cut along a line or cut out shapes on paper, with some
precision.

4AB9F37C92EA4A61ABCC8AA361887B38.description: Demonstrate limited precision and control in more complex fine motor tasks.

400CCC9FA1DF4A5787B5EFDEADF052FA.description: Make snips in paper with scissors.

3A086594BE8F41A481D64F0373278408.description:
Make repeated marks on paper to represent lines and circles, with these
shapes growing clearer with experience over time.

730D300D79734239B28E7036396FF917.description:
Draw or scribble to represent something they’ve seen or to convey a
thought.

1B08314255954BD992FB2259F1F0847F.description: Grasp writing tools with their thumb and fingers (pincer grasp).

81CF15DA9C6445DA8F034C833726A584.description:
Manipulate objects with hand-eye coordination, such as threading beads
with large holes onto thick string.

D8EA2AC3989C479E8C17F8436CB07CFB.description: Develop increasing control, strength, and coordination of small muscle groups.

5FF7904E7D4E4FE5A616B056F01A4D06.description: Children will demonstrate emerging understanding of writing as a way to communicate.

3565CFCBB1E34889A51BC27F30F9A910.description:
Actively participate in a story being read aloud by repeating or filling in
sounds, words, or actions throughout the story.

4B6E059F3F6146678BD0EE6B1D769391.description:
Learn and remember new information from the books they read or have
read to them, such as telling others that a platypus uses its nose to dig after
reading What Do You Do with a Tail Like This?

35CD234F62EB45D5B2F3D842238F6955.description:
Notice similarities between themselves and the characters in a story, or
between their own lives and what is happening in a story, such as saying “I
like lima beans too,” when reading A Bad Case of Stripes.

0BF79DB19E10464B9B1621328616A8C6.description: Identify the characters in a story.

C50255AB8CE9436697D693FB2B726A5A.description: Use flannel board pieces to retell a story.

A4143F31E9DA4CB99C6B6FDF6B3E42FC.description:
Use what they know about the characters and events of the story to make
predictions about what might come next.

A4271382B0404AA8BCFCBBEE9E26602A.description:
Ask and answer subjective or abstract questions about a story, such as
“How do you think the main character should solve their problem?” or “How
is the main character feeling? Why do you think they are feeling that way?”

837FD5665AC8475CB22496DB8568EE24.description:
Summarize a story, mentioning several key events or ideas and how they
connect the structure of the story.

934712414E04438AB21DB6BB18649BCA.description:
Identify the characters and main events of a story, as well as where the story
happens.

CEAAF36229244BCEA0AE7FC5D5688FCE.description:
Look at a picture and, with support and prompting, make up a story about
what is happening.

279910DAF1AA420B8948F3B258C43093.description:
Look at the pictures in an unfamiliar book to help them predict what might
happen next.

9AF556475371455E8766CF8A2A250701.description:
Show empathy for the characters in a story, such as worrying about Grover
in There’s a Monster at the End of this Book or saying that they are happy
when Max comes home to his family at the end of Where the Wild Things
Are.

D6DED419F3ED4C7994A43461C1260952.description:
Talk about possible consequences of a character’s actions, such as noticing
that the tree is bending in Chicka Chicka Boom Boom and wondering if the
letters will fall.

F5A09E709BB84F60B2FA4A499265B223.description:
Notice similarities to their own lives when being read a story, such as telling
another child that they made a snow angel yesterday when a familiar adult
reads about Peter making a snow angel in The Snowy Day.

FCBB12787D1F438A9DFA2CB5DB6E65FB.description:
Ask and answer factual questions about a text or story, such as “What was
the main character’s name” or “What comes next?”

19E95C4D52C241E392951019946AD728.description: Begin to run their fingers along the text in a book.

FFE628693F7641F2BAE8254419421966.description:
Begin to understand that the text on a page is separate or different from the
pictures.

540273A467F642C8939675BD3341DB5A.description:
Look at the pictures in a book when asked to describe what’s happening in
the story.

BA40B0FC20DB465994089F49AB28C58D.description:
Remember what will happen next when a familiar adult is reading a favorite
story aloud—for example, that the letters will fall out of the coconut tree at
the end of Chicka Chicka Boom Boom.

DABFA50D49A445DA88188F1138FDFE34.description:
Respond to silly, unrealistic situations in stories by laughing or expressing
disbelief, such as when the pigeon begs to drive the bus in Don’t Let the
Pigeon Drive the Bus!

B0EE0509F90E4D41911CD80692E8DEC9.description:
Remember events from earlier in a story, such as that the narrator of Green
Eggs and Ham does not like them in a house or with a mouse.

7F969EBF139B403DB26662B85F561EC4.description:
Answer a simple question about a story, such as “What is the cat wearing?”
“Boots!”

1BDB4C7F8AA448379558D2B8F64A1349.description: With support and prompting, describe what is happening in a picture.

628C5A10CBDE4314830402F2DD0B48D2.description:
Ask questions about what is being shown or happening in a particular picture
in a book.

79C08980D7394B4E8320D95A91203C2F.description:
Follow the text of a story left to right and top to bottom (if their home
language is English).

7864345757054307A59B2F5139799D39.description: Identify the parts of a book (front and back covers, title, author).

A1D02ACD7BAE494C8378BF86EF324A36.description: Follow the pages of a book left to right (if their home language is English).

BF8C3ECB290B41ABA9B9D970E3A48C22.description: Hold a book right-side up and with the front cover facing them.

37E718BF5F534B568C96890A722DD793.description: Pretend to read a book to a friend, stuffed animal, or pet.

C96B0CDAF8544060BDC2E00787F2FEBD.description: Use some language from a story when attempting to retell a story, such as saying “Chicka chicka boom!” as they turn pages in Chicka Boom Boom.

25B088D1D7C04AD39E1A46E872A404CC.description: Demonstrate reading-like behaviors with familiar text or print materials.

E0875991E68A4CB0BA692BA79D73B8EA.description: Children will interact with people and materials to increase their understanding of text.

3F409D45EC984AF8BC24F454E293D2E1.description: Identify the beginning and ending sound in words.

19E14A985AB34D02AD4C253DD1D5F515.description: With adult support, clap out the syllables of a word.

80FCCD6E30414D649FAB389A2FF43F93.description: Produce a series of rhyming words.

356CB4C7E232471980F31A0FBE64037E.description: When asked, identify whether two words start with the same sound.

C4E0C3EE5F7F407FBCA3C5CED87BC6DD.description:
Begin to recognize and identify separate syllables in words, such as in their
own name. For example: “A—ri—sa.”

2BACBEC6C38A441AB634BEE89FF40FE4.description: Identify the parts of compound words, such as book—shelf and race—car.

F7827BFE7C2F4F5986552C81C4CFA31B.description: Tell an adult that “here” and “cheer” rhyme but “here” and “there” do not.

5756700F28004D34B8F422F0E61906F8.description: Imitate and show enjoyment for rhymes and alliteration.

13317EF29CD44FDD905F0BA4EB82755D.description:
With adult support, identify when two words rhyme or begin with the same
sound.

B4889826518C4392A1127697CB5336FE.description: Recognize, manipulate, and play with sounds within words.

AF661EB456294BB99AB8CF7583464D46.description: Create and extend series of rhyming words.

6B517988CCEE4FA986A0C42CFCA795B3.description: Recognize final sounds in familiar words.

4BF10340CA29410082A43AE914594BC4.description: Recognize beginning sounds in familiar words.

3E8BCC24419A48BE9766C1BB935A49A1.description:
Recognize the difference between similar sounding words, such as blue and
glue.

3BCCE2FBED9446DF92EC9503391D431F.description: Identify rhymes in familiar words, games, stories, songs, and poems.

5621E146F61E4607925DFB0C7B359CF7.description: Recognize words that have matching sounds.

88A6FAC6F4BD43B8A87FBD553E66123E.description: Clap out the words in a song or sentence, with adult support.

AC13400064AC4780B9E4D0F89B5BDAD3.description: Say the last word of a repeating phrase in a familiar chant, song, or story.

F9FDFA30F1D44D8D86DC43691940659C.description:
Recognize some rhyming words, or words that sound the same, such as zip
and clip.

CB87B572A76A49DBB443DEA9F2E8B700.description: Act out the motions to familiar songs, chants, and fingerplays.

857046C0A73242E0B3A65B6AB82CB54A.description:
Notice and identify that some words start with the same sound, such as “cat
and cow start with kkkkk.”

49FFFDC3DE124431962D00C65CA626DD.description: Notice, manipulate, and play with the sounds of language.

8999526A12F145DC96CC520FCC0184AC.description:
Children will build their awareness of, and ability to work with, the sounds of
language.

4C9201DC0D8E49ABAC5392D61212A222.description:
Use invented spelling as they sound out new words, with and without adult
support.

500155B81A464B94ACC6108B2C6AF41A.description: Identify letters based on hearing their associated letter sounds.

B5D5B33F9EBE4BB0903B87F09CD91EF0.description:
Produce the letter sounds associated with the letters in their own name, with
adult support.

4E6B130EFBDF4C8A9CABE52690B3628F.description:
Make the letter sound associated with the first letter of a word, with adult
prompting.

E2BD45573D8E4F20A241E3EFD2F0BD15.description: Make the sounds associated with many of the letters they recognize.

4D58D8ED29D84C9D8B871313C202481E.description: Recognize the sounds associated with letters.

07A8502ADB8C44DE8898E4F083545421.description: Differentiate between uppercase and lowercase letters.

11BBA38C58B944DD8F360330423BEA5A.description:
Recognize and identify at least 18 uppercase and 15 lowercase letters by
the end of their prekindergarten year.

F693E46DF8484D7B8BC8183F4B61BDB6.description:
Recognize the printed form of their own name and other names of familiar
people (classmates, family members, etc.).

751E212A85374140B4A5EECFA18F5F34.description: Recognize and identify many uppercase and lowercase letters.

168DCF0F334D4C95A824CEC64F048574.description:
Recognize and identify the letters in their name when they appear in other
printed words.

BF0236F3113647C195CC7CF934B156B5.description:
Sort and/or match letter shapes, without necessarily being able to name or
identify those letters.

FB44BB8E3A7845BFBE5B64B54CD57149.description:
Notice a letter appearing in printed words as being the first letter of their
name.

BEB6212BD9E94152A9BA939B002BE1D2.description: Identify some frequently appearing letters and numbers.

FA775BE6DB914EFB8D37E9DE632611F0.description:
Recognize letters, the names of letters, and how the letters are shaped, as well as some personally
meaningful words.

21912E214D1F47A0A38690BF2F0BB9B7.description:
Children begin to understand that (in alphabetic languages like English) letters and
letter sounds represent the sounds of the spoken language.

7EECB1B144604FE7AB7D985D8C241B2C.description:
Use a device to record video of a gymnastics meet they attended and play it
back later when telling others about the experience.

6C641331F6A44E0CA506C4B067AB4868.description: Draw a picture of and write about the elephant they saw at the zoo.

9E16F8D3943B40C59A4D3CC5E71430CD.description:
Express their thoughts, experiences, and ideas using a variety of strategies,
including gestures and facial expressions, words, signs, pictures, text,
numerals, sounds, shapes, models, and photographs.

5C662E24B0D542AF8BA7F99D4B9525D0.description: Point to and talk about words and pictures in a variety of texts.

DFB5FDFBE96748AAB6D78194F7A2380B.description:
Finish the ends of repeating phrases or complete a rhyme or sentence
while an adult reads a book, such as “He ate through one apple, but he was
still....” “Hungry!”

D93FC7F1A70A45B8A47B725FBF624F6D.description: With support and prompting, describe what is happening in a picture.

AD65985E29F248B985245BA51FD637B2.description:
Use some language from a story when attempting to retell a story, such as
saying “Boom boom!” as they turn pages in Chicka Chicka Boom Boom.

241412EE9BC74D49A2031E675205263F.description:
Understand that print and pictures communicate ideas that can be read/viewed and understood
by others.

41AB855B3C4144D18A84E4B3BFD2CBF4.description:
Point to individual, sequential words on a page as they read (or attempt to read) each
word.

1DABC5D515474291B30CF6685DAD66B4.description: Track text from left to right, top to bottom, and page to page.

4B89BC4BA4C6432997CBED7AAB5F018B.description:
Recognize and show interest in the ways people use print, such as reading a story
about getting letters in the mail and then asking a familiar adult to send them a letter in
the mail or making and “reading” a grocery list during pretend play.

9DBC140FE9B947B7ADE205ED8F922AA9.description:
Begin to recognize the difference between letters, words, and sentences, such as
pointing out the word that starts with a particular letter.

958DB15901E04412862165930D02A3B4.description: Mimic and repeat familiar story routines, such as saying “the end” at the end of a book.

C29D01CF03F6448D9EC6375B51B93C4F.description: Begin to run their fingers along the text in a book.

0ECD5EA3E1A5401592678659A53F7884.description: Join in with adults saying “the end” at the end of a book.

9AFE97E2873F4576B4729BEE705091F4.description: Begin to understand that the text on a page is separate or different from the pictures.

47616B9381FF4019A92BE46341A57A59.description:
Begin to use pictures and logos in environmental print to attempt to decode the text,
such as a new label in the learning environment with a picture of a Crayola crayon
box to identify the basket of crayons, a picture of a STOP sign to wait at the end of a
hallway, or the red and white bullseye image to identify a Target store.

95C4F1AEA3A6475DB26AA69411D5B70C.description: Expand their environmental print vocabulary with some less familiar signs and logos.

F937F6480D8743A2A680AAD4A46F7C71.description: Demonstrate an understanding of print concepts.

4BE9D31731D14F8EB0871B710346674A.description:
Hold books upright and with front cover facing them and turn individual
pages to read a story either using the text or the pictures, or a combination
of both.

5496D58840ED4C14A671DF9BDA348763.description:
Turn to the approximate part of the book and then turn pages to find specific
parts of a story in the book.

866A7E9F01074105850FF7C5CA7D69A7.description:
Ask about, identify, and distinguish between the roles authors and illustrators
play in making a book.

11A750DD1D1E485DB7DB3AFC5F80BFC4.description:
Identify the parts of a book: the front and back covers, top and bottom, and
title.

B3EA9193ED8146EF9355D075DC22E012.description: Hold books with two hands and turn the pages.

CD4567BF96464569B53A8FAFBC69B946.description: Choose familiar books to “read” to themselves or to a doll or stuffed animal.

3BB954A473F84898BF6214BD9EF49259.description: Demonstrate interest in and care for books, including book handling concepts.

8EDFC75A7DE34DF695B97BD8E01CEE09.description:
With support and reminders, apply their understanding of conversational
routines, such as turn-taking and maintaining eye contact, to a variety
of situations and types of conversations (with a familiar adult, a peer, an
unfamiliar adult, at home, etc.) with increasing consistency.

EEC3862073B34614A35B03B69E6693FF.description:
Initiate conversations and stay on topic during through multiple turn-taking
exchanges.

791CEBE0F14C40F3BAA8128A5B5BC124.description:
Engage in peer-to-peer conversations, listening and responding while
staying on topic.

45FE4B4C3BCA4D66B9F08624A4BBC12A.description: Stay on topic during peer-to-peer and group conversations.

729629FDE9144E5B8F3C3E9099588612.description:
With some support and reminders, apply their understanding of
conversational routines, such as turn-taking and maintaining eye contact,
to a variety of situations and types of conversations (with a familiar adult, a
peer, an unfamiliar adult, at home, etc.).

EFD46381263F49619AEEBF92BE06BDDF.description:
Adjust their language and tone when having a conversation with younger
children.

FF393757F47D4D028AA75D1861BB38FC.description:
Adjust their volume and tone depending on the context of their conversation,
such as speaking with a friend or an unfamiliar adult, having a conversation
in the learning environment or in a public library.

AD0121DFE167491BB1C942A8133604B6.description:
Use nonverbal cues during conversations according to their personal
cultural context, including physical proximity, maintaining eye contact, asking
questions, etc.

B6AAF3FE37024D2E9D306AD1B00BA3F2.description:
With modeling and support, begin to apply their understanding of
conversational routines, such as turn-taking and maintaining eye contact,
to a variety of situations and types of conversations (with a familiar adult, a
peer, an unfamiliar adult, at home, etc.).

CF81E8F5C1DE4823981BDF8FA19487E2.description:
Take turns in conversation by initiating and sustaining a simple back and
forth conversation.

5C6D4F556D964445AD372C7A494C8E73.description: Show attention to a person they are having a conversation with.

BA16AC28046F4F219F9AAAFF7D6A982F.description:
With modeling and support, use polite terms such as please, thank you, and
excuse me with increasing consistency.

B24B67B2E49E495484C338E5332054FB.description: Follow the social expectations of their personal cultural context when communicating with others.

AEDDD6ABD62946C9BF39396A11C64843.description:
Return to previous topics of conversation with new information “Remember, I
told you about the zoo? This is a picture of the tiger!”

2C8AE30C4C3D4D9C98F1C48D8FD2D98F.description: Engage in a wider variety of conversational topics.

3B1E131082DB48D38660308FC944F77D.description:
Extend conversations by asking questions and making comments related to
the topic.

8FADCBB69B2440F8A66563CC21597677.description: Retell a story or describe one of their own experiences in sequence.

724C7BACEDDC4DA082F1904645201DB0.description: Tell a story out loud for a familiar adult to write down.

7FAF0E24AFB34091BA49BB4A32655B0A.description:
Hold extended back-and-forth conversations by asking questions and
making comments related to the topic, sometimes.

D26E02C54937484582A9BD181C9EDF80.description: Begin to hold longer back-and-forth conversations.

DFF5879F0370408D93E3ADB14511293B.description: Initiate and respond to communication with others.

89A8CC75B71148379928F319AB45897E.description: Communicate with others for a variety of purposes.

36049CB63FE1487AAEB1113077BE82CB.description:
Children use social and conversational skills, beginning with their home language
and cultural values.

ED05FEF7F1034A0D8668CA764980BE76.description: Use sentence structures that are grammatically complex, most of the time.

00C5BB617DBA49C2B5750AE2FEC7C33F.description:
Combine words and phrases into increasingly complex sentences. For
example: “Teisha’s moms came today and read us a story and they took
turns doing different voices!”

A0E25CF709504F5E84FC3709CCA0B925.description: Tell increasingly detailed stories about their lives.

253E786C2B9846889323EB1202C04AD5.description:
Use sentence structures reflective of their home languages, such as
adding adjectives after nouns (rather than before nouns, as in English). For
example: “I have a shirt blue.”

B8AE490E8A36406EB2CCBFF235FF3F0F.description:
Combine words and phrases into increasingly complex sentences. (e.g.,
“She doesn’t like peas, but I do!”)

70D3F757E3504357B2677C86777E8BF0.description:
Use plurals as well as past and future tense verbs correctly when telling
stories, most of the time. For example: “We went to the zoo. We saw two
tigers and I got popcorn!”

D4BB39F6BC704A9DA32A876FEFF14B6A.description:
Tell stories about their experiences using past, present, and future tenses
and terms interchangeably (e.g., “yesterday we go to the zoo”).

1A93A336066F4370BAB5E725C1861FA7.description:
Combine simple words into sentences, using plurals, past tense, subjectverb agreement, and the possessive form (although often incorrectly). For
example: “Mommy goed work.”

EFDC07018C554093A95B9046B6103948.description: Communicate using increasingly complex grammar and sentence structure.

04ADA0E5DA814A9FAD373F41282721AA.description: Describe events that happened in the past with many details.

5AC066817E6640A68CD7B63C7AF332D9.description: Ask specific questions to understand and solve problems.

A1B4E0F1238641A8854E258AAE5953E1.description:
Demonstrate an increasingly complex and varied vocabulary of over 1000
words or signs.

91F959584FB9467886D812C7DD3494AC.description: Answer questions with detailed and more abstract signs, words, and ideas.

1222E46B92A84C67B3ADFD6204C719F6.description: Combine 5-8 words or signs together into complete thoughts or sentences.

ECFF959485E54ACE9328287614B3B419.description: Use questions to ask for things or gain information.

6E9978C1B92E4B6D92F73A99F608A259.description:
Use their growing vocabulary to express their needs and describe objects,
relationships between objects, emotions, and actions, including an
increasing number of details.

7C401BFDC7224D458BBB5B53D53CFF83.description:
Demonstrate a broad and increasing vocabulary of about 500 words or
signs.

3D69B2F5C6324BCEADE995FC55CFD609.description: Use phrases and sentences of 4-5 words or signs.

D597F7C487254F37AAE579E14BE82A39.description: Answer simple questions with words or signs.

E5E193541E854033BAF701C410A873A3.description: Use phrases and sentences of 2-3 words.

BD3D4DAFECE64157B925D135DAB43330.description:
Use an increasingly complex and varied vocabulary to express their needs
and describe objects, relationships between objects, emotions, and actions.

66DAD539BB4E4657B7EEDCF0BB0F7511.description: Communicate clearly, using increasingly detailed signs, words, phrases, and sentences.

5EB93EEDE9414B05BACE40F5F9C3C1C1.description:
Begin to use some polite gestures that are commonly used in their family
and community, such as bowing to indicate respect, lowering their gaze
when speaking to adults, or greeting a friend with a hug.

985F06BC375C4B8FB108B4BD6384126C.description:
Still mispronounce some words, especially new, unusual, or complex words,
such as “buhsghetti” for spaghetti.

789377177D8E48B2A259CD6F38C301F9.description: Communicate clearly enough to be understood by most people.

B2B556BEB17D4B8F93ADB86903401D37.description:
Communicate using increasingly understandable language, including sounds, gestures, signs,
words, and language expressed using assistive devices.

D11AAB0649224F10B02E936846611253.description:
Children use language to express themselves to others, beginning with their home
language.

4D0C6814FE12404493E7EA2F0B6986C4.description:
Follow increasingly detailed, multi-step instructions, such as “Please put
away your markers and put your picture in your cubby, then choose a book
and join us on the carpet.”

B0ED5F0D4B5D486584F92B2C41B966A1.description: Follow multi-step instructions, such as “Put away your markers, choose a book, and come join us on the carpet.”

A1AA8FA0F80C4CADBEA72A98C10492E7.description:
Respond to repeated signs, words, and phrases with gestures and body
movements.

04A9079E1E2B44D3B8CBD1CD819B5DAF.description:
Follow one- or two-step directions that involve familiar experiences or
objects, such as “Pick up the ball and roll it to me,” or “Choose a book and
come sit down.”

6B2800B580384AFCBABB024AE4D7F4B2.description:
Participate in a group conversation by communicating their own perspective
when asked, such as by explaining that the classroom hamster likes yogurt
treats during a discussion about making sure their pets have what they need
to be healthy and happy.

72A07C18893546FAA361A193C28E1012.description:
Retell or use picture cards to identify the major events in a story they just
listened to.

0821A874D16A482EA5E21A98654139CD.description:
Show attention during primarily receptive interactions, such as listening to a
book being read aloud, by nodding, gesturing, interrupting to ask a related
question, etc.

4FF10ABEC584494E8ED9230D8228C5D7.description:
Show attention during longer and more complex conversations, either
spoken or signed.

67373A92D2DC4E57BDB162F811E3325F.description: Actively listen to short presentations and remember some details.

90EA821178D3472E85009C34A35EE432.description:
Listen attentively to a peer or adult when it is that person’s turn to talk during
a conversation.

DA48AEBDA0044F44B97129BE686AAF8C.description:
Answer when asked questions such as “Why do you think your friend is
sad?” “What happened to the block tower when you bumped into it?” “Who
can you ask for help with that?” or “Where could we look to find the answer
to that question?”

536074A9D6AE4D6DB968C461B722498F.description:
Listen to a story about a boy in the rain and respond with reasons from the
story when asked “Why did the boy in the story have wet shoes?”

80FF173A3C644E7AB54A1CA616C9B6C0.description:
Answers questions or points to objects/people when asked questions such
as “Who do you want to play with?” “What colors will you use to color the
dinosaur?” “Where is your backpack?” or “What do you want to play with?”

5EB70ED2109744E3BE04F31E57771AA2.description:
Listen as a familiar adult describes an idea or clarifies the meaning of a
word.

48F66A842D674E9CAAE21F5E2A51B1CA.description:
Respond yes or no (or nodding/shaking their head) when asked “Do you
want to go outside?”

CEDE46D7198047C09562C42FA994B193.description:
Bring the box of dinosaurs to the carpet when a familiar adult tells them that
dinosaurs are one of the choices to play with.

7794E9FEBC2542C395417DC3D014FD87.description:
Pick out a book from the bookshelf and bring it to a familiar adult when
asked to choose the next story to read.

7630095F8BF44D78A571F5EEA9422019.description:
Participate in conversations by showing attention and acknowledging
comments or questions, either spoken or signed.

CAF7BD2877A746B6B888F7ECBEED56EA.description: Demonstrate understanding of increasingly complex language, including non-verbal cues.

E588A11B22534131A25AEF32DCB09DCA.description:
Children develop an understanding of language, beginning with their home language
or dialect.
